identity of this fossil with the recent types, has been strongly confirmed
by the circumstance, that among the Paris Basin forms I have
found the minute specimen represented in Plate II Fig 9;
which corresponds in every respect with the <s>young</s> simple type of the
existing species.

70  Of the other fossil species cited by Lamarck, the <u>O
Macropora</u> of the Maestricht beds, judging from the figure
given of it by Goldfuss, is nothing else than an Orbitolite of
simple type, such as that of which a portion is represented in
Plate II Fig 7, with its marginal cells, both above and below, laid
open by attrition, as in Plate X, Figs 4. 3. The <u>O. concava</u> and
<u>O. rileolus</u> of Lamarck are not distinguished in his definition by
any other character than that drawn from <u>form</u>, which we have
seen to be so variable as to be quite insufficient as a distinctive
feature. It is quite possible, moreover, that they may belong to another
type; nothing being said in the description of them, either of
concentric lines, or of pores. If, as I believe, the <u>O. concava</u> of
Lamarck (figured by Michelin in his Icon. Zoophyt Plate vii Fig.
9) be identical with the <u>O conica</u> of M D'Archiac, I feel
